subject: Testing philosophy question
msgSnippet: Here s one for you: I m helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java in their own time and once a week I do a small lunchtime chalk and talk session.
messageBody:
Here's one for you:

I'm helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java in their own time and once a week I do a small lunchtime "chalk and talk" session. Lately, I have started introducing JUnit, on the grounds that the sooner I teach them good habits, the more likely they are to stick with them. I'm using the java.lang.String class as the object being tested, so that we only have to worry about writing one class instead of two.

My question is: When testing overloaded methods (String.indexOf() in this specific case), is it better for each overloaded method get it's own testXXX() method or is it ok to lump them all in the one test? I have them all in one test right now, on the grounds that the test is against the index feature, rather than the individual methods.

Thoughts please.

Simon

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@...
Java Programming Specialist www.landsend.com
Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526

"Wisdom is not the prerogative of the academics." - Peter Chappell
